title: Project
text:
This project studies how the installation of electric vehicle (EV) charging stations affects nearby economic activity. In particular, I ask whether EV charging stations increase local visitation to nearby businesses, such as restaurants and retail stores, and whether these effects differ across neighborhoods.



Data source

Kansas City Electric Vehicle Charging Record
Mobility Data

Methods

I use a panel data approach to compare business visitation before and after the installation of EV charging stations. The analysis relies on a difference-in-differences framework, with fixed effects to control for time-invariant characteristics of locations and common time trends. Distance-based measures are used to define treated and control areas around charging stations.

Expected outcomes

I expect EV charging stations to increase visitation to nearby businesses by attracting drivers who spend time charging their vehicles. The results may also reveal heterogeneous effects across business types and neighborhood characteristics. This project aims to provide evidence on the local economic impacts of EV charging infrastructure.

title: Week 2 Release (Instructor)
text:
Week 2 Release (Instructor)
This folder simulates content that is present in the repository but can be kept “hidden” from students until you tell them to switch branches.
Recommended approach: - Keep main minimal for Week 1. - Create a branch like week2 that adds an assignments/ folder. - When ready, tell students: git checkout week2 (or merge week2 into main).
This repository includes a sample release/week2/assignments/ directory you can move into place.

title: Student Website Assignment — Quick Start
text:
Create and publish a simple personal website using Quarto and GitHub Pages.




index.qmd (Home)
about.qmd (About)
project.qmd (Project)
_quarto.yml (Site title and navigation)





Open each .qmd file and replace placeholder text with your own.
Open _quarto.yml and set website: title: to your name.
Commit and push to GitHub.





Go to Actions and confirm workflows are green (successful).
Go to Settings → Pages and look for your site URL.

If you do not see Pages, your instructor may have enabled the deployment environment view instead.






Deleting _quarto.yml
Renaming files without updating the navbar in _quarto.yml
Pushing to a branch other than main





Include a screenshot of the error from Actions → workflow run → logs.

title: Assignment 01 — Add a CV page
text:
Assignment 01 — Add a CV page

Create a new file called cv.qmd
Add it to the navbar in _quarto.yml
Add a short CV section (Education, Experience, Skills)
Render and push

title: Grading Rubric — Student Website (100 points)
text:
Repository contains required Quarto website files and builds in GitHub Actions


Clean commit history (at least 3 meaningful commits; messages are descriptive)


README updated with student name and short description







Home page: clear welcome, purpose, and navigation cues


About page: substantive bio (not placeholder text)


Project page: clear question/topic, data or motivation, methods/plan







Navbar present and functional across pages


Consistent headings, readable layout, and correct spelling/grammar


External links (if used) work and are appropriate







Site renders without errors; required pages exist in _site/


No broken internal links (e.g., navbar targets exist)


GitHub Pages deploy succeeds (site is reachable)






You are graded on the rendered site AND the repository content.
If a build fails, fix it and push again before the deadline.

title: About
text: I am Junxian Tang(Larry), a second year PhD student in Energy Environmental&Food Economics Program. I am interested in energy and environment sectors. I choose this course becuase I want to enhance my knowledge of Causual Inference.
